title: Human-AI Collaboration in Crowd-Powered Systems: A Framework for Transparent Task Allocation
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
abstract: We present a comprehensive framework for transparent task allocation in crowd-powered AI systems. Our approach combines human-in-the-loop machine learning with explainable task routing to improve both efficiency and worker satisfaction. Through a large-scale deployment with 500+ crowd workers, we demonstrate significant improvements in task completion quality while maintaining transparency in algorithmic decision-making.

title: Value-Sensitive Design of AI-Mediated Community Platforms
venue: Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction (CSCW)
abstract: This paper investigates how value-sensitive design principles can be integrated into the development of AI-mediated community platforms. Through a multi-stakeholder participatory design process, we identify key tensions between efficiency and fairness in algorithmic content curation.

title: Adaptive Crowdsourcing for Complex Information Needs
abstract: We propose an adaptive crowdsourcing framework that dynamically adjusts task complexity and worker selection based on real-time quality signals. Our system leverages Bayesian optimization to balance exploration and exploitation in worker-task matching.

title: Human-in-the-Loop Data Integration with Active Learning
venue: International Conference on Very Large Data Bases
abstract: We introduce a human-in-the-loop approach for data integration that combines active learning with crowd-powered verification. The method reduces the number of human judgments needed by 60% while maintaining integration quality.

title: Modeling User Behavior in Crowd-AI Hybrid Systems: A Survey and Framework
venue: ACM Transactions on Interactive Intelligent Systems
abstract: This survey provides a comprehensive overview of user modeling approaches in hybrid crowd-AI systems. We analyze 150+ papers and propose a unified framework that categorizes behavioral signals, modeling techniques, and application domains.

title: Fairness Perceptions of Algorithmic Decision-Making in Crowdsourcing
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
abstract: We study how crowd workers perceive fairness in algorithmic task allocation and payment decisions. Through a mixed-methods study with 300 workers, we identify key fairness dimensions and design implications for more equitable crowdsourcing platforms.

title: Crowd Computing: Foundations, Methods, and Challenges
abstract: This chapter provides a foundational overview of crowd computing, covering task design, quality control, worker modeling, and integration with machine learning pipelines.

title: Conversational Search with Human-AI Collaboration
venue: ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval
abstract: We present a conversational search system that seamlessly integrates AI-generated responses with crowd-sourced verification to improve result reliability and user trust.
